revision.text:
{{Infobox Military Unit |unit_name=Egypt Command
British Troops in Egypt |image= |caption= |country={{flag|United Kingdom}} |type=[[Formation (military)|Command]] |branch={{army|United Kingdom}} |dates=1882–1956 |specialization= |command_structure= |size= |current_commander= |garrison=[[Cairo]] |battles= |notable_commanders= }} '''Egypt Command''' was a [[British Armed Forces|British military]] [[Formation (military)|command]]. By the mid-1930s and throughout the [[World War II|Second World War]] the command's title had become '''British Troops in Egypt'''. ==History== The command was established in the late 19th century after the [[Anglo-Egyptian War (1882)|Anglo-Egyptian War]] in 1882.{{cite web|url=http://www.britishmilitaryhistory.co.uk/documents.php?aid=40&nid=6&start=0|title=British Troops in Egypt 1930 – 45|publisher=British Military History|accessdate=23 August 2014}} The British Army remained in [[Egypt]] throughout the [[World War I|First World War]] and, after the War, remained there to protect the [[Suez Canal]]. Following Egypt's independence in 1922, the [[United Kingdom]] and Egypt entered into a [[treaty]] in 1936 whereby British troops remained to protect the canal and to train the [[Egyptian Army]]. After the [[World War II|Second World War]] anti-British resentment escalated and there was rioting in the streets in February 1946. British troops left Egypt in June 1956 shortly before the [[Suez Crisis]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/british/modern/suez_01.shtml|title=The Suez Crisis|publisher=BBC|accessdate=23 August 2014}} ==Commanders== Commanders were as follows:{{cite web|url=http://www.gulabin.com/armynavy/pdf/Army%20Commands%201900-2011.pdf|title=Army Commands|accessdate=23 August 2014}} *1899–1903 Major-General [[Reginald Talbot|Sir Reginald Talbot]] *1903–1905 Major-General [[John Slade (British Army officer)|John Slade]] *1905–1908 Major-General [[George Bullock (British Army officer)|George Bullock]] *1908–1912 Major-General [[John Maxwell (British Army officer)|Sir John Maxwell]] *1912–1914 Major-General [[Julian Byng, 1st Viscount Byng of Vimy|Julian Byng]] *1914–1915 Lieutenant-General [[John Maxwell (British Army officer)|Sir John Maxwell]] *1915–1916 General [[Sir Charles Monro, 1st Baronet|Sir Charles Monro]] *1916–1917 Lieutenant-General [[Archibald Murray|Sir Archibald Murray]] *1917–1919 Field-Marshal [[Edmund Allenby, 1st Viscount Allenby|Viscount Allenby]] *1919–1923 Lieutenant-General [[Walter Norris Congreve|Sir Walter Congreve]] *1923–1927 General [[Richard Haking|Sir Richard Haking]] *1927–1931 General [[Peter Strickland (British Army officer)|Sir Peter Strickland]] *1931–1934 General [[John Burnett-Stuart|Sir John Burnett-Stuart]] *1934–1938 General [[George Alexander Weir|Sir George Weir]] *1938–1939 Lieutenant-General [[Robert Gordon-Finlayson|Sir Robert Gordon-Finlayson]] *1939–1941 Lieutenant-General [[Henry Maitland Wilson, 1st Baron Wilson|Sir Henry Maitland Wilson]] *1941–1941 Lieutenant-General [[Richard O'Connor|Sir Richard O'Connor]] *1941–1941 Lieutenant-General [[James Marshall-Cornwall|Sir James Marshall-Cornwall]] *1941–1942 Lieutenant-General [[William Holmes (British Army officer)|William Holmes]] *1942–1944 Lieutenant-General [[Robert Stone (British Army officer)|Robert Stone]] *1944–1948 Lieutenant-General [[Charles Walter Allfrey|Sir Charles Allfrey]] *1948–1949 Lieutenant-General [[Richard Gale (British Army officer)|Richard Gale]] *1949–1952 Lieutenant-General [[George Erskine|Sir George Erskine]] *1952–1954 Lieutenant-General [[Francis Festing|Sir Francis Festing]] *1954–1956 Lieutenant-General [[Richard Hull|Sir Richard Hull]] ==References== {{Research help|Mil}} {{reflist}}
